Situation2: A flash-flood warning triggers building alarms as water rises along the block.
Story: The shrill ring of my phone echoed in my ears as I stared at the text from Jamie, my best friend. My heart dropped—my careless joke at lunch had clearly cut deeper than I realized. I knew I had to call Jamie right away, to apologize, to explain, to be the friend I promised I’d always be. But just as I reached for my phone, the building’s emergency alarms blared, and a neighbor pounded on my door. “Flash flood! We need everyone’s help to sandbag the entrance!” I looked out the window; water was already pooling in the street. As a citizen, I knew I was needed—my community depended on everyone pitching in during emergencies like this. But Jamie’s pain was urgent too, and I couldn’t bear the thought of letting our friendship fester another minute. My hands shook as I stood in the hallway, torn between dialing Jamie’s number and rushing downstairs to help. The weight of both expectations pressed on me, each demanding my immediate attention, and I felt paralyzed, caught between being the friend Jamie needed and the citizen my neighbors counted on.
